conversation.content: The service order says penthouse unit, some fancy imported refrigerator that's—wait, [stunned pause], Jamie? Jamie Rodriguez from Franklin Street?
[guarded] Hey, Marcus.
[disbelieving] I saw you on the cover of Rolling Stone at the grocery checkout last week, and now you're standing here in your old Nirvana shirt like nothing's changed.
[defensive] Everything's changed, actually, which is why I had to call for repair service instead of just asking you to come over like the old days.
[hurt] You could have called me directly, you know, instead of going through the company dispatcher and pretending we're strangers. [quieter] I still have the same number.
[uncomfortable laugh] I didn't know if you'd want to hear from me after I left without saying goodbye properly, just that stupid text from the airport.
[working while talking] This compressor's completely shot, probably from being unplugged and replugged during your tours—these European models don't handle power fluctuations well.
[wistful] Remember when we tried to fix your mom's freezer that summer after graduation and ended up flooding the entire garage?
Yeah, except now I actually know what I'm doing, got certified and everything while you were learning to play stadiums. [pause] Your mom still asks about you at the hardware store.
[softly] She does? I keep meaning to visit but the label has me scheduled every second, and when I do get home, I just hide up here.
[focused on work] You're hiding in a three-million-dollar penthouse, Jamie—that's not exactly suffering in silence like we used to joke about.
[pleading] Don't do that, don't make it about the money when you know that's not what matters between us.
[bitter laugh] Right.
[urgent] I tried to bring you with me, remember? Offered to hire you as my tech manager, but you said you didn't want to be anyone's charity case.
[firmly] I'm good at what I do, Marcus who fixes things, not Marcus who follows his famous friend around carrying guitar cases.
[frustrated] It wasn't charity, I needed someone I could trust, and now I'm surrounded by people who only see dollar signs when they look at me. [breaking slightly]
[softer now] The compressor'll take three days to ship from Germany, but I can jerry-rig a temporary fix to keep your food cold until then.
Three days? [hopeful pause] That means you'll have to come back, actually come back here to install it?
[carefully neutral] That's the job, yeah, though usually I'd send one of the junior techs for the follow-up installation. [sighs] But I guess I can make an exception.
Maybe we could get coffee after, like we used to at that place on Riverside—if it's still there, if you have time, if you want to.
